content.title: Dan Ives Calls Import Tariffs "Armageddon." Should You Really Buy Tech Stocks Now?
content.summary: Investors piled into technology stocks over the past couple of years on optimism that artificial intelligence (AI) could become the next great revolution.  Unsurprisingly, tech stocks led gains in the Nasdaq Composite (NASDAQINDEX: ^IXIC), but they also drove the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJINDICES: ^DJI) and the S&P 500 (SNPINDEX: ^GSPC) higher.  Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) and Palantir Technologies posted the top performances in those two indexes, respectively, last year.

content.title: Up 17% in 2025, Has Warren Buffett-Led Berkshire Hathaway Run Up Too Far, Too Fast?
content.summary: Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE: BRK.A) (NYSE: BRK.B) is up 17% year to date (YTD) at the time of this writing -- handily crushing an 8.3% decline in the S&P 500 (SNPINDEX: ^GSPC).  Berkshire Hathaway has been on such a tear that it is one of the top 40 best-performing S&P 500 components in 2025.  Hovering around an all-time high, Berkshire's market cap is now $1.15 trillion -- making it the sixth-most valuable U.S. company behind Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL), Microsoft, Nvidia, Amazon, Alphabet, and Meta Platforms.

content.title: Tesla and Apple Stand To Take The Biggest Tariff Hits
content.summary: Tesla and Apple will be among the top U.S. companies most badly damaged by President Trump's tariff campaign, Wedbush analysts said in a pair of research notes.  For Tesla, the resulting trade war is a double whammy, they noted.  China is also a key region for Tesla, and Trump's tariffs have created a backlash against Elon Musk there that will drive customers to BYD and other Chinese competitors, they added.

content.title: Tesla Stock Dives Again. Price Target Slashed 43% Amid Musk’s ‘Brand Crisis Tornado.’
content.summary: Tesla  stock was tumbling in premarket trading Monday after longtime bull Wedbush analyst Dan Ives slashed his price target.  Shares of the electric vehicle maker were down 3% in premarket trading at $231.92, while  and  futures were dropping 2.1% and 2.6%, respectively.  Ives lowered his price target from a Street high (among major brokers) of $550 a share to $315 a share, down 43%.

content.title: What Does Trump's Tariff Hike Mean for Consumer Goods Investors?
content.summary: This past week, President Donald Trump announced his full plan for tariffs on imports -- a list of duties varying by country that could make a wide range of goods pricier for U.S. companies and consumers.  The concern for investors is that these higher prices will weigh on corporate earnings in two ways.  First, higher prices will hurt consumers' buying power, leaving them with less to spend on discretionary items.

thumbnail.caption: A sign with "tariffs" written on it and a U.S. flag in front of the Capitol.

content.title: History Says the Best Time to Buy Stocks May Be Coming
content.summary: President Donald Trump's trade wars are creating significant uncertainty, while many fear that a recession might be coming -- something else that could send the stock market in the wrong direction.  The Nasdaq Composite and S&P 500 have both recently hit correction territory -- defined as a 10% drop from their most recent highs.  Predicting these things is hard, but a bear market is a real possibility.

Despite Amazon's bid to acquire TikTok grabbing headlines, market dynamics were largely overshadowed by broader economic fears as the Nasdaq entered bear market territory. The market plunged by 9.4% with tariffs contributing substantially to investors' unease, affecting various sectors...

content.title: 3 Top Bargain Tech Stocks Ready for the Next Bull Run
content.summary: Following President Donald Trump's "Liberation Day" tariff announcement, stocks plummeted as fears escalated regarding a potential global trade war and how it could impact the global economy.  While there certainly could be more pressure on stocks in the coming weeks depending on how this all plays out, it also has created some solid entry points for several top tech stocks where investors can start to at least dip their toes into the stocks.  Let's look at three bargain tech stocks investors can consider buying now.

content.title: Britain's JD Sports underperforms market rout on US exposure
content.summary: Shares in British sportswear retailer JD Sports Fashion underperformed a stock market rout on Monday, reflecting both its heavy exposure to key partner Nike and U.S. tariffs.  Ahead of a trading and strategy update scheduled for Wednesday, shares in JD Sports were down 6%, taking losses over the last month to over 18%.  The FTSE 100 index of blue chip stocks was down 4% on fallout from U.S. President Donald Trump's tariff announcement last week.

content.title: Billionaire Investor Bill Ackman Calls for 90-Day Pause on Tariffs
content.summary: Bill Ackman is calling for a 90-day pause on the implementation of President Trump’s reciprocal tariffs.  “I have a lot of respect for our president and what he has accomplished so far, but I don’t think he is infallible, which is why I am stating loud and clear that I strongly believe launching tariffs on April 9th against the entire world — massively in excess of what we are being charged — is a mistake,” said Ackman in a post on the social-media platform X.  In another post earlier in the day, Ackman warned about “a self-induced, economic nuclear winter” if President Trump doesn’t pause the tariffs to prevent further economic fallout.

content.title: Why Nike Stock Rose in a Brutal Day for the Market
content.summary: Nike (NYSE: NKE) stock managed to post gains Friday despite another big sell-off for the broader market.  Stocks sold off again today as investors assessed the unfolding outlook on tariffs, but Nike was able to close the day in the green thanks to what could be a key development on that front.  President Trump said that he had a productive call on tariffs with Vietnam's leaders, and investors are hoping that could open the door for the footwear and apparel giant to see mitigated headwinds.

content.title: Prediction: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Will Soar Over the Next 5 Years. Here's 1 Reason Why.
content.summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (NYSE: TSM) is the world's leading semiconductor (chip) foundry.  Its foundry business model means it makes chips tailored to its customers' specific needs, and key partners include Nvidia, Apple, and Advanced Micro Devices.  To see how vital the company, also known as TSMC, is to AI development, it's important to work backward, beginning with the end product: AI applications.
